Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolutionary Consequences of Pathogen Strain Competition in an Emerging Fungal Disease
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the interplay of ecological competition and evolutionary dynamics among different strains of pathogenic fungi. Newly discovered, emerging diseases are a significant threat to biological diversity and human health. Many of these emerging diseases are caused by fungal pathogens. Yet few studies have addressed the evolutionary ecology of disease-causing fungi. A notorious emerging fungal disease is the amphibian-killing chytrid fungus, which is contributing to worldwide amphibian declines and biodiversity loss. Despite intensive research since its discovery in 1999, the origins and evolutionary trajectory of this disease remain a mystery. This project will investigate a region of high chytrid diversity in the Atlantic Forest of southern Brazil to understand how competition among different fungal strains determines the success and evolution of these pathogens. Understanding how emerging diseases evolve will be critical to controlling future disease outbreaks. The project includes the training of undergraduate and graduate students, along with K-12 outreach programs and museum displays that highlight effects of introduced diseases on ecosystem health.

Prior research suggests that divergent amphibian-killing chytrid strains in Brazil's Atlantic Forest are competing for hosts. According to theory, competing disease strains should evolve to have faster rates of growth and increased virulence until a single most successful strain has eliminated all others. This project will investigate how these chytrid disease strains initially came into contact, and the ecological and evolutionary outcomes of this contact. The researchers will reconstruct the divergence history of Brazilian Atlantic Forest disease strains using whole genome sequences of pathogen isolates collected from the region. They will then conduct a cross-strain competition experiment on a model amphibian host. The genomes of experimental pathogen strains will be sequenced before and after the experiment to link genotypic changes to phenotypic change in post-competition virulence. These data will allow the researchers to establish the timing of contact between pathogen populations, and to determine if accelerated virulence evolves due to direct competition among strains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Newly discovered diseases, also known as emerging diseases, are one of the greatest current threats to biodiversity and human health. Studies examining recent emerging diseases show a curious increase in those caused by fungi. Fungal pathogens (fungi that cause disease) are biologically distinct from bacteria and viruses, yet few studies have addressed their evolutionary ecology. One of the most notorious of these emerging fungal diseases is the amphibian-killing chytrid fungus because of its role in amphibian extinctions worldwide and its significant contribution to biodiversity loss. Despite over a decade-and-a-half of concerted research since its discovery in 1999, the basic ecology and evolutionary trajectory of this disease remain a mystery. A better understanding of how emerging diseases evolve will be critical to controlling future diseases outbreaks, especially as pathogens are increasingly brought into contact by human activity. We investigated a region of high chytrid diversity in the Atlantic Forest of southern Brazil to understand how competition shapes the evolution of these pathogens. Prior research in the Brazilian Atlantic Forest has suggested that divergent amphibian-killing chytrid strains in the region are under competition for hosts. We predicted that competing disease strains will be selected for faster growth and higher virulence until a single most successful strain has excluded all others. Given the potential consequences of pathogen strain competition on disease virulence; this project aimed to understand the genetic differences between these disease strains, and what the outcome of strain contact will be. 

To understand the consequences of strain contact, we carried out an experiment in which we coinfected the same host frog with two divergent strains of chytrid fungus. We utilized a novel host frog, the dwarf African frog, and developed a highly sensitive molecular test using digital PCR to accomplish this experiment. Our results showed that over ten weeks, chytrid strains belonging to the globally invasive genotype outcompeted endemic Brazilian genotypes in these coinfection trials. These are the first such results showing that in a coinfection scenario, amphibian chytrid strains show a hierarchy of competitive ability with the most competitive strains able to persist in the population at the expense of other genotypes. The implications of these results are wide ranging as diverse pathogen strains are increasingly transported between continents, expanding opportunities for contact. The human-mediated altering of pathogen populations though competition holds the potential to introduce conservation risks where invasive strains establish. To understand the genomic basis underlying these competitive differences we generated whole genome sequences of 51 amphibian chytrid strains for analysis. We identified regions of the genome that were most divergent between the globally invasive and Brazilian endemic strains. These genomic regions showed high representation by genes that function in tolerating oxidative stress, a mechanism that may confer greater competitive ability to highly virulent, invasive strains of this disease. One manuscript describing our results in currently in peer review and another is in the advanced stages of preparation. This project provided research training and laboratory experience for three female undergraduate students. The project also involved three major K-12 outreach experiences. These outreach activities provided an opportunity to introduce topics in ecology and biodiversity conservation to approximately 200 middle and elementary students in partnership with a local natural history museum and participating school districts.
